| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              | [SLASH'EM\_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1644](/wiki/SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1644 "SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/monst.c") |

- *For the monster in [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack") and [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), see [Pegasus (EvilHack)](/wiki/Pegasus_\(EvilHack\) "Pegasus (EvilHack)").*

**Pegasus**, u, is a [unique](/wiki/Unique "Unique") [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM") and [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"). It is a [strong](/wiki/Strong "Strong"), [inediate](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate") [horse-like](/wiki/Unicorn_or_horse "Unicorn or horse") [animal](/wiki/Animal "Animal") that is capable of [flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight").

Pegasus has a [kick](/wiki/Kick "Kick") attack and a bite attack.

## Generation

Pegasus is always generated as peaceful.

Pegasus will only generate when [Medusa](/wiki/Medusa "Medusa") is killed in a manner that leaves a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse"), which causes Pegasus to appear from her remains - though Pegasus is flagged as a unique monster, Medusa can be revived with [turn undead](/wiki/Turn_undead "Turn undead") and killed again, creating another Pegasus.

## Strategy

Pegasus is an excellent [steed](/wiki/Steed "Steed") candidate for an aspiring tamer, with the same base speed as a [warhorse](/wiki/Warhorse "Warhorse") and the ability to fly - the only obstacle is its [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") of 70, which means it may take a while to tame with the [spell of charm monster](/wiki/Spell_of_charm_monster "Spell of charm monster"). Additionally, Pegasus is inediate and will eventually turn feral if mounted enough times by most characters, minus [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") and [Yeomen](/wiki/Yeomen "Yeomen") - the latter's [calm steed](/wiki/Calm_steed "Calm steed") [technique](/wiki/Technique "Technique") can increase Pegasus' tameness after each mount.

Pegasus will always leave a corpse unless [disintegrated](/wiki/Disintegrate "Disintegrate") or killed over [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava"), providing ample opportunity to revive him with a [wand of undead turning](/wiki/Wand_of_undead_turning "Wand of undead turning").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Pegasus](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pegasus "wikipedia:Pegasus")***

Pegasus (Greek *Πήγασος* "Pḗgasos", Latin *Pegasus* or *Pegasos*) is a winged horse in classical mythology, usually depicted as a winged white stallion. Depending on the telling, he and his brother Chrysaor were both born when Medusa was decapitated by [Perseus](/wiki/Perseus "Perseus"), or else sprang from her blood as it was spilled upon the earth, with the latter reflected by its generation method. Long honored as a constellation, Pegasus is a subject of very rich iconography, especially through ancient Greek pottery as well as paintings and sculptures of the Renaissance.

According to early myths, Pegasus created fountains wherever his hooves touched the ground, with one of these springs being the Hippocrene ("horse spring") of Mount Helicon. Despite the association with Perseus, Pegasus figures much more in the most famous tale of the Greek hero Bellerophon: he captures Pegasus near another fountain with the help of Athena and Poseidon, and the winged horse allows Bellerophon to ride him in order to defeat the monster Chimera. Later, Bellerophon rode Pegasus towards Mount Olympus, prompting Zeus to send a gadfly to sting Pegasus and throw Bellerophon off to his demise - in almost all tellings, Pegasus himself would make it to Olympus, where he was used to carry Zeus's thunderbolts.

[![This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.](/images/3/38/Se7e7-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article may require revision for the next version of SLASH'EM. Click here for more information.")

[![This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.](/images/5/5d/Nh343var-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article describes a 3.4.3-based variant of NetHack. Click here for more information.")

Pegasus

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
u Pegasus
Difficulty 14
Attacks Kick 2d10, Bite 1d6
u Pegasus
Difficulty 14
Attacks

Kick 2d10, Bite 1d6

Base level 12
Base experience 277
Speed 24
Base AC 2
Base MR 70
Alignment 7 (lawful)
Frequency (by normal means) Unique
Genocidable No
Weight 1500
Nutritional value 350
Size Large
Resistances None
Resistances conveyed None

Pegasus:

  • can fly.
  • has no hands.
  • is an animal.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is normally generated peaceful.
  • wanders randomly.
  • is strong.
Reference SLASH'EM_0.0.7E7F2/monst.c#line1644
For the monster in EvilHack and Hack'EM, see Pegasus (EvilHack).

Pegasus, u, is a unique monster that appears in SLASH'EM and SlashTHEM. It is a strong, inediate horse-like animal that is capable of flight.

Pegasus has a kick attack and a bite attack.

Generation

Pegasus is always generated as peaceful.

Pegasus will only generate when Medusa is killed in a manner that leaves a corpse, which causes Pegasus to appear from her remains - though Pegasus is flagged as a unique monster, Medusa can be revived with turn undead and killed again, creating another Pegasus.

Strategy

Pegasus is an excellent steed candidate for an aspiring tamer, with the same base speed as a warhorse and the ability to fly - the only obstacle is its MR score of 70, which means it may take a while to tame with the spell of charm monster. Additionally, Pegasus is inediate and will eventually turn feral if mounted enough times by most characters, minus Knights and Yeomen - the latter's calm steed technique can increase Pegasus' tameness after each mount.

Pegasus will always leave a corpse unless disintegrated or killed over lava, providing ample opportunity to revive him with a wand of undead turning.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Pegasus

Pegasus (Greek Πήγασος "Pḗgasos", Latin Pegasus or Pegasos) is a winged horse in classical mythology, usually depicted as a winged white stallion. Depending on the telling, he and his brother Chrysaor were both born when Medusa was decapitated by Perseus, or else sprang from her blood as it was spilled upon the earth, with the latter reflected by its generation method. Long honored as a constellation, Pegasus is a subject of very rich iconography, especially through ancient Greek pottery as well as paintings and sculptures of the Renaissance.

According to early myths, Pegasus created fountains wherever his hooves touched the ground, with one of these springs being the Hippocrene ("horse spring") of Mount Helicon. Despite the association with Perseus, Pegasus figures much more in the most famous tale of the Greek hero Bellerophon: he captures Pegasus near another fountain with the help of Athena and Poseidon, and the winged horse allows Bellerophon to ride him in order to defeat the monster Chimera. Later, Bellerophon rode Pegasus towards Mount Olympus, prompting Zeus to send a gadfly to sting Pegasus and throw Bellerophon off to his demise - in almost all tellings, Pegasus himself would make it to Olympus, where he was used to carry Zeus's thunderbolts.

Retrieved from "https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Pegasus&oldid=169897"

{{For|the monster in [[EvilHack]] and [[Hack'EM]]|Pegasus (EvilHack)}}

'''Pegasus''', {{monsym|pegasus}}, is a [[unique]] [[monster]] that appears in [[SLASH'EM]] and [[SlashTHEM]]. It is a [[strong]], [[inediate]] [[Unicorn or horse|horse-like]] [[animal]] that is capable of [[flight]].

Pegasus has a [[kick]] attack and a bite attack.

==Generation==
Pegasus is always generated as peaceful.

Pegasus will only generate when [[Medusa]] is killed in a manner that leaves a [[corpse]], which causes Pegasus to appear from her remains - though Pegasus is flagged as a unique monster, Medusa can be revived with [[turn undead]] and killed again, creating another Pegasus.

==Strategy==
Pegasus is an excellent [[steed]] candidate for an aspiring tamer, with the same base speed as a [[warhorse]] and the ability to fly - the only obstacle is its [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]] of 70, which means it may take a while to tame with the [[spell of charm monster]]. Additionally, Pegasus is inediate and will eventually turn feral if mounted enough times by most characters, minus [[Knight]]s and [[Yeomen]] - the latter's [[calm steed]] [[technique]] can increase Pegasus' tameness after each mount.

Pegasus will always leave a corpse unless [[disintegrate]]d or killed over [[lava]], providing ample opportunity to revive him with a [[wand of undead turning]].

==Origin==
{{Wikipedia|Pegasus}}
Pegasus (Greek ''Πήγασος'' "Pḗgasos", Latin ''Pegasus'' or ''Pegasos'') is a winged horse in classical mythology, usually depicted as a winged white stallion. Depending on the telling, he and his brother Chrysaor were both born when Medusa was decapitated by [[Perseus]], or else sprang from her blood as it was spilled upon the earth, with the latter reflected by its generation method. Long honored as a constellation, Pegasus is a subject of very rich iconography, especially through ancient Greek pottery as well as paintings and sculptures of the Renaissance.

According to early myths, Pegasus created fountains wherever his hooves touched the ground, with one of these springs being the Hippocrene ("horse spring") of Mount Helicon. Despite the association with Perseus, Pegasus figures much more in the most famous tale of the Greek hero Bellerophon: he captures Pegasus near another fountain with the help of Athena and Poseidon, and the winged horse allows Bellerophon to ride him in order to defeat the monster Chimera. Later, Bellerophon rode Pegasus towards Mount Olympus, prompting Zeus to send a gadfly to sting Pegasus and throw Bellerophon off to his demise - in almost all tellings, Pegasus himself would make it to Olympus, where he was used to carry Zeus's thunderbolts.
